quotes.topic_title: Cold open: LinkedIn feed turnaround and AI-first
quotes.text: If you start from the premise that LinkedIn ultimately is a platform for economic opportunity that sits on top of a very strong social graph. Almost every aspect of economic transaction is possible.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A clear first-principles framing of LinkedIn’s product strategy as an economic opportunity platform built on a social graph.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: LinkedIn feed turnaround and AI-first
quotes.text: To really set the new purpose for it, which was this is not a springboard for other products. This is not a traffic jumpstart, it's not an upsell feed. It's really about people that matter, talking about things that I care about professionally. The first thing we did was really making AI first.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Defines a contrarian repositioning of the feed away from growth/upsell mechanics toward relevance and professional value, anchored by an AI-first shift.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: LinkedIn feed turnaround and AI-first
quotes.text: So it wasn't like, "Oh, we have this cool technology, what can we do with it?" It was like, "Let go of what you've built. Go back to the objectives you were trying to solve and now with this technology, how can you do that objective better?"
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A practical methodology for adopting AI: start from objectives, not tech novelty, and be willing to reset existing solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: LinkedIn feed turnaround and AI-first
quotes.text: AI is the ultimate matchmaker. It's underutilized, it's misunderstood, it's really about...
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A memorable mental model positioning AI’s core value as matching—useful for thinking about recommendations, discovery, and marketplace dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And he was also at the center of shifting LinkedIn to an AI first mindset, which started way before AI became cool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a contrarian leadership move: adopting an AI-first strategy early, before it was an industry trend.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Tomer goes inside the strategy behind the transformation of LinkedIn's feed and how they approached making it a place that people wanted to check and make it much more social.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Points to a practical product methodology: intentionally redesigning a core surface (the feed) around repeat visitation and social utility.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also get into the one mindset that Tomer credits for helping him rise so quickly within LinkedIn.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Signals a transferable career-growth lever—an explicit “mindset” tied to rapid progression in a large org.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We might be wrong, but we are not confused.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable decision-making mantra emphasizing clarity and alignment even under uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: Tomerism: “We might be wrong, not confused”
quotes.text: But probably I might be wrong but not confused.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A memorable mantra that prioritizes organizational clarity and commitment over being correct.

quotes.topic_title: Tomerism: “We might be wrong, not confused”
quotes.text: Their company was on the brink of failure. They had their last attempt and they decided on a path forward and after they decided on a path forward, he was still seeing people hedging in different directions and it led into this confusion in the system where we decided people are still hedging, they're still trying out things they thought could work, and he realized that unless they basically all pull through in the same direction, there is no chance they'll be able to be successful.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how hedging after a decision creates system-wide confusion and undermines execution.

quotes.topic_title: Tomerism: “We might be wrong, not confused”
quotes.text: Now, pulling through in the same direction doesn't mean you're going to be successful, but this gives you a chance of success and that confusion, the system only luck and save you.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that alignment doesn’t guarantee success, but confusion almost guarantees failure without luck.

quotes.topic_title: Tomerism: “We might be wrong, not confused”
quotes.text: And for me it comes down to two main parts. One is clarity of thought and clarity of execution, and they're both equally important.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A simple two-part framework practitioners can use to diagnose and improve decision-making and follow-through.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Gamma has become one of the fastest growing AI web products in the world, adding 20 million new users just this past year and is setting its sights on becoming the modern alternative to PowerPoint.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete growth data point and positioning statement that signals how quickly AI-native tools can displace incumbents.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What I find people to be attached to, especially when you build an environment with a lot of alpha types is that they get attached to being right or wrong and that really creates a lot of lingering in the system, a lot of confusion and they're still stuck to their ideas.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Highlights a common team dynamic that slows execution: identity tied to correctness rather than progress.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And for me, I get attached to clarity and focus.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A simple operating principle practitioners can adopt to reduce thrash and align decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I would rather go forward with everybody in the same direction than necessarily try to hedge all the time, which will give me no chance of success.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on prioritizing alignment and commitment over risk-hedging to increase odds of execution success.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The way we start, we do this in our product gens right now, is we actually spend some significant time on what is the problem we're trying to solve for, but not high level, not like, hey, we want to launch this product, we want to launch a video product.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Describes a practical methodology for product planning: invest upfront in defining the real problem at a non-generic level.

quotes.topic_title: Clarity in practice: principles and resourcing
quotes.text: And for me, I get attached to clarity and focus. I think that's much more important.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A simple operating principle for high-ego environments: optimize for shared clarity over being right.

quotes.topic_title: Clarity in practice: principles and resourcing
quotes.text: It's exactly what type of video you're trying to launch for which audience, what is your unique criteria, what are you trying, what is very nuanced about what you're trying to solve for?
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A practical standard for problem statements: specificity about audience, criteria, and nuance before discussing solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Clarity in practice: principles and resourcing
quotes.text: But saying that I'm willing to sacrifice or trade off this, that's where I get excited.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A test for strong product principles: they become real only when they include explicit tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Clarity in practice: principles and resourcing
quotes.text: "Hey, just push back. Are you disagreeing or misunderstanding? If you're misunderstanding, let's spend the night. Let's get to a point where you can articulate my point of view in your words and I can do the same, but if we're disagreeing, let's stop. Why are we spending? Why wasting time just arguing it through?"
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A meeting-level decision rule that prevents masked disagreement from wasting time and forces explicit alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Clarity in practice: principles and resourcing
quotes.text: You have to make sure that what you're sharing as a priority is actually manifested in your resourcing.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete execution check: priorities are only real if staffing and talent allocation match them.

quotes.topic_title: Why clarity is liberating for teams
quotes.text: When you need to move forward and it's not about being right or wrong, it's really about not being confused and making sure everybody's pulling in the same direction.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A practical reframing: optimize for shared clarity and alignment over being “right,” which helps teams execute faster.

quotes.topic_title: Why clarity is liberating for teams
quotes.text: I also think it's the best way to learn. If you don't know exactly what you're doing, how can you learn back from why you made that decision?
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Connects clarity to learning loops—clear decisions make outcomes diagnosable and improve iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Why clarity is liberating for teams
quotes.text: How can I have a product conversation if I'm not sure what you stand for?
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Highlights that productive debate requires explicit positions; otherwise feedback and decision-making break down.

quotes.topic_title: Why clarity is liberating for teams
quotes.text: If you ask folks how many time you left a meeting in corporate, it could be a startup or larger companies and you are not sure exactly what was the problem discussed or what are next steps. More often than not, they'll raise their hand.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete, relatable example of how unclear meetings waste time and why teams should insist on explicit problem/next steps.

quotes.topic_title: Ambitious goals and “share the peak” vision
quotes.text: For me it's like we are here to make an impact. We're here to really set our goals to something really massive.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A clear leadership stance on setting goals that are intentionally huge to drive real product impact.

quotes.topic_title: Ambitious goals and “share the peak” vision
quotes.text: When I'm trying to visualize this, I see a mountain, you see the peak and the peak exactly how it looks like, you see base camp, you know how to start and maybe the middle of the mountain is kind of blurry, but you'll figure this out.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for product strategy: be crisp on the destination and starting point even if the path is unclear.

quotes.topic_title: Ambitious goals and “share the peak” vision
quotes.text: But at least you know the peak you're trying to share, share the peak, share where you're headed to and I think it's just a much more exciting way to build product.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to align teams by explicitly communicating the end-state vision (“the peak”).

quotes.topic_title: Ambitious goals and “share the peak” vision
quotes.text: I don't start building from the numbers today. I start from [inaudible 00:15:04] I start backwards. I'm like, what this could be, what is the potential here?
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A contrarian approach to planning: work backward from potential rather than anchoring on current metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Ambitious goals and “share the peak” vision
quotes.text: Again, it's not detached from reality completely, but it's also not hooked to it.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A useful calibration principle for ambitious goal-setting: avoid both fantasy and incrementalism.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn feed turnaround: purpose and AI engine
quotes.text: What you find is it's actually, most of the time it's internally harder to do because there's so much entrenched flows and processes and metrics that people are using on that specific area.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive turnaround lesson: the biggest obstacles are often internal incentives and legacy metrics, not the market.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn feed turnaround: purpose and AI engine
quotes.text: one of the main things we've done was to really set the new purpose for it, which was this is not a springboard for other products, this is not a traffic jumpstart for, it's not an app self feed, it's really about people that matter talking about things that I care about professionally.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A clear purpose statement that product teams can use to realign priorities away from internal traffic goals toward user value.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn feed turnaround: purpose and AI engine
quotes.text: The first thing we did was really making AI first.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A simple operating principle for feed-quality turnarounds: treat AI as the primary lever, not a downstream implementation detail.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn feed turnaround: purpose and AI engine
quotes.text: So what I did was I carved out two million members and I said, "Those are my members. I'm going to focus on building that mountain peak. I'm going to build for them."
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for de-risking disruptive changes: isolate a large cohort to iterate freely without triggering org-wide dependency panic.

quotes.topic_title: LinkedIn feed turnaround: purpose and AI engine
quotes.text: Today we had 140 hours of learning every minute on LinkedIn happening across the feed and LinkedIn Learning, it's pretty powerful.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A specific scale data point that supports the strategic framing of the feed as a knowledge-exchange engine.

quotes.topic_title: Carving out 2M users and choosing feed KPIs
quotes.text: But for us, they were like the world we were basically able to prove with them.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A practical methodology: isolate a small cohort that becomes your “whole world” to validate a risky bet before scaling.

quotes.topic_title: Carving out 2M users and choosing feed KPIs
quotes.text: I felt that I tried for a few months to play on the overall experience with everybody, but it was really hard, almost like impossible because you have an organization that is so tied into how things work that I was just hitting walls after walls after escalations and it was just unproductive.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lesson: broad, company-wide changes can be organizationally impossible, so carve-outs can be the only productive path.

quotes.topic_title: Carving out 2M users and choosing feed KPIs
quotes.text: I can't just count how many folks engage with the feed because then I'm counting bypassers kind of thing and bystanders that are actually coming into the experience.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A KPI design warning: top-level engagement metrics can be misleading when the surface is a default landing experience.

quotes.topic_title: Carving out 2M users and choosing feed KPIs
quotes.text: So we actually started to look at the more, we go a lot into active, engaged and high value engagement. So we go downstream, we kind of put the onus on looking at more downstream engagement there and we build that as the feed engagement.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete measurement approach: define success via downstream, high-value engagement rather than shallow top-of-funnel activity.

quotes.topic_title: Carving out 2M users and choosing feed KPIs
quotes.text: If you want to keep the site keep growing and the experience keep growing, carving out and almost like sending very specific unique metrics but then could easily be extended out once you show it was in retrospect the right way to do it.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A scalable experimentation playbook: run with unique metrics in a carve-out, then extend once proven without destabilizing the core business.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction-led product bets and thinking time
quotes.text: I start from beliefs a lot.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A simple mental model for identifying big opportunities: begin with conviction about what could be true, not what currently is true.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction-led product bets and thinking time
quotes.text: I think it's really hard to be a strong product leader without having strong conviction about something.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Highlights conviction as a core product leadership capability practitioners can cultivate and use to guide big bets.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction-led product bets and thinking time
quotes.text: So I don't get attached to what did not work in the past.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive stance that challenges the common tendency to over-weight past failures when evaluating future opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction-led product bets and thinking time
quotes.text: I think LinkedIn has a great process called vision to values that started from our former CEO, Jeff Winner, which is like if you said this is for company or for a product, which is if you're successful, what change would happen in the world?
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete framing practitioners can use to define success in terms of world-change outcomes rather than output metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Conviction-led product bets and thinking time
quotes.text: I tend to lead with beliefs versus evidence. I try to prove my beliefs with evidence, but I don't lead with evidence.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A practical methodology for making conviction-led bets while still validating them rigorously after forming the initial thesis.

quotes.topic_title: AI matchmaking for creators and consumers
quotes.text: The understanding is is that in a marketplace, if I'm able to satisfy your need on the other side, then it's magic.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A simple marketplace mental model: optimize for cross-side need satisfaction to create compounding engagement.

quotes.topic_title: AI matchmaking for creators and consumers
quotes.text: So ultimately it came down to AI is the ultimate matchmaker. It's underutilized, it's misunderstood, it's run separate from the team.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A contrarian operational takeaway: AI creates the most leverage when it’s integrated into core product teams rather than siloed.

quotes.topic_title: AI matchmaking for creators and consumers
quotes.text: And in a marketplace it's all about value exchange. And if I'm able to do value exchange really well, then people will come back and they do and they engage and actually they come back even more and they spend more time.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for marketplace products: measure and improve value exchange to drive retention and time spent.

quotes.topic_title: AI matchmaking for creators and consumers
quotes.text: Making sure that when you share something, you share your expertise. The right people on the other side are relevant to your content and they see it. That could make your day or your week or actually it could make your living in many ways.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A practical creator-side goal for feed ranking: reliably route expertise to the most relevant, high-impact audience.

quotes.topic_title: AI matchmaking for creators and consumers
quotes.text: He's like, "I'm getting speaking engagements that are roughly half the salary I make in a year here at the university. Just by people seeing this content and getting to the right people. I was invited to advise prime ministers on their investment strategy for the country and I've been teaching for 20 years, but this platform just completely elevated my ability to reach and influence people."
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete example of AI-driven matchmaking translating distribution into major economic opportunity and influence.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their single API helps SaaS companies launch over 200 product integrations in weeks, not quarters.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete data point on speeding up integration delivery timelines using a single-API approach.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think of Merge like Plaid, but for everything B2B SaaS, organizations like Ramp, Dorada and Electric use Merge to access their customer's accounting data to reconcile bill payments, file storage data to create searchable databases in their product or HRIS data to auto-provision and deprovision access for their customer's employees.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Memorable analogy plus specific examples of integration use cases that product teams can map to their own roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And yes, if you need AI ready data for your SaaS product, then Merge is the fastest way to get it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable takeaway that integration infrastructure can be a lever for making product data AI-ready quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing an AI-first mindset at LinkedIn
quotes.text: And when I say AI first, it's not about a tech, it's a mindset. It's a start with strategy.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Reframes “AI-first” away from tools and toward a strategic operating model practitioners can adopt immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing an AI-first mindset at LinkedIn
quotes.text: The analogy I would give to people is imagine a river rafting boat and you have everybody on the sides holding the pedals and adding accuracy, adding speed, but there's the guide on the back and they're holding those two pedals. Those two pedals navigate pretty much the boat and those pedals are AI and the guide better be you.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why product leaders must directly steer AI/algorithms rather than delegating them as a “black box.”

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing an AI-first mindset at LinkedIn
quotes.text: When it came to the feed where I push for example, more specifically for the teams, he doesn't stay as an AI first, there's the objective. I would ask him, "What is the objective of the algorithm?" I would challenge you to ask folks more in the folks who are leading products specifically with algorithms inherited built into them, what is the objective of the algorithm and can you write it down for me on a board?
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, actionable review question PMs can use to operationalize ownership of algorithmic products.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing an AI-first mindset at LinkedIn
quotes.text: In fact, you should go all the way to infrastructure. You can have massive lifts in your product outcomes and goals if you probably enhance your infrastructure. How many product people talk about the infrastructure they have? Not many.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that PMs should treat infrastructure as a primary product lever, not just an engineering concern.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing an AI-first mindset at LinkedIn
quotes.text: So coming into this role in early 2020, we basically established an AI academy. Every PM had to go through training just like we did mobile in 2014, we moved the whole organization to be mobile first, so everybody had to go through this process.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A specific operational example of institutionalizing an AI-first shift via mandatory training, modeled after a prior “mobile-first” transformation.

quotes.topic_title: Letting go of control: AI as ingredients
quotes.text: And I think this is one of the biggest shifts with this when you become an AI first leader, is that there's a realization that you don't control the experience anymore, you control the ingredients.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for AI-first product leadership: shift from deterministic UX control to defining inputs, constraints, and components.

quotes.topic_title: Letting go of control: AI as ingredients
quotes.text: Obviously you build safety guards and responsible AI around it and that's super critical. But at the essence of it, AI is not deterministic.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A practical reminder that guardrails are necessary, but teams must design for non-determinism rather than pretending AI behaves like traditional software.

quotes.topic_title: Letting go of control: AI as ingredients
quotes.text: So giving it the rope to learn and do that experience for you ultimately would become much, much better. You have to have that belief going into it.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance: performance improves when you allow the model room to operate (within guardrails), requiring a mindset shift toward iteration and learning.

quotes.topic_title: Letting go of control: AI as ingredients
quotes.text: But we didn't start with new objectives to solve. So it wasn't like, "Oh, we have this cool technology, what can we do with it?" It was like go back to the objectives you were trying to solve and now with this technology, how can you do that objective better?
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: A concrete methodology to avoid “AI everywhere” traps: start from existing user/business objectives and reimagine solutions with AI.

quotes.topic_title: Letting go of control: AI as ingredients
quotes.text: The second part is we actually allowed teams to run to really inspire creativity. I didn't want to contain them.
quotes.speaker: Tomer Cohen
quotes.context: An execution tactic for early AI product discovery: temporarily loosen constraints to maximize exploration and surface unexpected approaches.
